captions.text: A regular day starts at 01:50.

People think you're crazy
to get up that early.

But I've been doing this for so long
I have no problems with it.

Here I come, 30 metres long
and I weigh 90 tons.

Roger Henriksson is a test driver for
Swedish research project One More Pile.
A project where size really matters.

By adding an extra pile, timber
transport becomes more productive

fuel efficient
and environmentally friendly.

The long-term goal of the project,
which started in 2007

is to change Swedish
load limit legislation
to allow 90 tons instead of today's 60.
Roger sits comfortably in a Volvo FH16.

So far, the 30 meter and
90 ton vehicle combination
doesn't seem to bother him.

Sure, it was scary at first,
checking your rear view
and it seems to go on forever.
"How do I drive a truck that long?"

And, of course,
there was the weight as well.

How does it perform
under such a heavy load?
For its length, it's very agile.

Twice a day, four days a week,
Roger drives the same two-hour stretch

between the towns of Överkalix
and Munksund, transporting timber.

He's used to driving
the same route every day.

And it doesn't bother him, even if his
colleagues find it a bit odd.
My friends who are also truck drivers

don't understand how you can drive
the same route all the time.

But I told them
that you can't ponder that.

That once I'm done in Piteå,
I have to go get another load.
You can't ponder that.

I have a job that I enjoy
and I try to do it as best I can.

I think I'll keep
doing this job, well...

As long as I have the energy. So I hope
for at least 15-20 more years.

title: Volvo Trucks - A 30 metre and 90 tonne FH16 timber truck in northern Sweden - Driver’s World (E05)
